text: The genius of the pre-mortem ritual is the initial prompt. So it's not just about like, well, what could go wrong? The initial prompt is the genius, which is the prompt starts with, imagine this project that we are working on has failed six months from now, or this launch we are doing has miserably failed. Let's just all imagine that. Now, let's work backwards from there and ask ourselves what went wrong, what could have contributed to this utter failure.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks Shreyas to explain the concept of pre-mortems, which is something he's shared on Twitter that has resonated with many people. Shreyas explains that pre-mortems are the opposite of post-mortems - instead of analyzing what went wrong after a project fails, you proactively imagine failure at the beginning of a project. The key insight is using a specific prompt that asks the team to work backwards from an imagined failure scenario to identify potential risks before they occur.
text_ko: 사전 실패 시뮬레이션(pre-mortem) 의식의 천재성은 바로 초기 프롬프트(prompt)에 있어요. 단순히 “뭐가 잘못될까?” 하는 수준이 아니라, 핵심은 처음에 던지는 질문이에요. 그 질문은 이렇게 시작하죠. “우리가 지금 하고 있는 이 프로젝트가 6개월 뒤에 실패했다고 상상해 보세요,” 또는 “이번 론칭이 처참하게 실패했다고 가정해 봅시다.” 자, 그럼 그 상태에서 역으로 거슬러 올라가 무엇이 잘못됐는지, 어떤 요인들이 이런 완전한 실패에 기여했을지를 함께 찾아보는 거예요.
text_zh: 事前验尸(pre-mortem)这个方法最厉害的地方就在于一开始怎么问问题。不是简单地问"会出什么问题"，关键是一开始就要这样想：假设我们现在做的这个项目，六个月后彻底搞砸了，或者我们要上线的东西完全失败了。大家先这样想象一下。然后我们倒推回来，想想到底哪里出了问题，什么原因导致了这次惨败。
text_es: La genialidad del ritual de pre-mortem está en cómo empiezas. O sea, no se trata solo de preguntarse "¿qué podría salir mal?" La clave está en el planteamiento inicial, que empieza así: imagínense que este proyecto en el que estamos trabajando fracasó completamente dentro de seis meses, o que este lanzamiento que vamos a hacer fue un desastre total. Vamos todos a imaginarnos eso. Ahora, trabajemos hacia atrás desde ahí y preguntémonos qué salió mal, qué pudo haber contribuido a este fracaso absoluto.
key_sentence: The genius of the pre-mortem ritual is imagining utter failure and working backwards from it.

text: I noticed consistently over the years that as I started thinking about what differentiates the PMs who've had just a large impact and even more important than just impact to the company or to the team, PMs who've surprised me in a positive way, PMs who've really exceeded expectations, exceeded perhaps their own capabilities on paper. You see somebody's credentials on paper and then you see their work and their impact. And there's a big difference between what you might assume on paper and the impact they're achieving.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny brings up the concept of high agency as an important trait for product managers. Shreyas explains his observations about what separates high-performing PMs from those who underperform relative to their potential. He's noticed that some PMs consistently exceed expectations despite not having the most impressive backgrounds, while others with great credentials fail to achieve their potential in practice.
text_ko: 제가 수년 동안 꾸준히 느낀 건, 큰 임팩트를 낸 프로덕트 매니저(PM)들과, 더 중요한 건 팀이나 회사에 실질적 영향을 주면서도 저를 긍정적으로 놀라게 한—기대치를 훨씬 넘긴—프로덕트 매니저들이 무엇으로 차별화되는지 생각해 보면 공통된 패턴이 있다는 점이에요. 이력서나 스펙만 보면 어떤 사람일지 짐작하게 되는데, 실제로 그 사람이 만들어내는 성과와 영향력은 종종 종이에 적힌 것과 크게 달라요.
text_zh: 这些年我一直观察发现，那些真正有巨大影响力的PM(产品经理)，不只是对公司或团队有贡献，更重要的是那些让我刮目相看的PM，那些真正超出预期的PM，甚至超越了他们纸面实力的PM。你看他们简历上的背景资历，再看他们实际的工作表现和影响力，纸面印象和实际成果之间往往差别很大。
text_es: Me he dado cuenta a lo largo de los años que cuando me pongo a pensar en qué diferencia a los PMs que han tenido un impacto enorme, y más importante aún que el impacto para la empresa o el equipo, son los PMs que me han sorprendido para bien, PMs que realmente han superado las expectativas, que han ido más allá de lo que parecían capaces sobre el papel. Ves el currículum de alguien y luego ves su trabajo y su impacto real. Y hay una diferencia abismal entre lo que podrías asumir viendo su papel y el impacto que realmente están logrando.
key_sentence: PMs who exceeded expectations often differ greatly from what you assume on paper.

text: When you combine high energy sound judgment, low ego and small teams, you just get magic. And so, Stripe wasn't by any means flawless, but I saw that combination of high energy sound judgment, low ego and small teams more at Stripe than any other place I've been at. And so, that was very impactful and my growth and thinking as a leader.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks Shreyas what he took away from each of the major tech companies he worked at - Yahoo, Google, Twitter, and Stripe. Shreyas is explaining the key lesson he learned at Stripe about what creates exceptional team performance. He observed that when you combine four specific elements together, it creates an almost magical level of productivity and results.
text_ko: 높은 에너지와 건전한 판단력(high energy, sound judgment), 자만심이 낮은 태도(low ego), 소규모 팀(small teams)을 결합하면 진짜 마법 같은 일이 일어나요. Stripe가 결함이 전혀 없던 건 아니지만, 제가 가본 어느 곳보다도 그 조합을 Stripe에서 더 자주 봤어요. 그래서 그 경험이 제 리더로서의 성장과 생각에 큰 영향을 미쳤어요.
text_zh: 当你把高能量、靠谱的判断力、低姿态还有小团队这几个东西组合在一起的时候，就会产生神奇的化学反应。Stripe当然不是完美无缺的，但是我在那里看到的这种高能量、靠谱判断力、低姿态加上小团队的组合，比我去过的任何地方都要明显。这对我作为领导者的成长和思维方式影响特别大。
text_es: Cuando combinas mucha energía con buen criterio, poco ego y equipos pequeños, simplemente surge la magia. Y mira, Stripe no era para nada perfecto, pero vi esa combinación de mucha energía, buen criterio, poco ego y equipos pequeños más en Stripe que en cualquier otro lugar donde haya estado. Y eso me impactó muchísimo en mi crecimiento y forma de pensar como líder.
key_sentence: High energy, sound judgment, and low ego create magic in small teams, even if not flawless.

text: Most execution problems that I encounter in a high performing environment where everybody has the right intentions are actually not execution problems, they are either strategy problems or interpersonal problems or cultural problems. And so, just to illustrate it, I'll make the observation that many leaders are extremely busy in such environments, whether it's a fast growth startup or a fast growth larger company, they're extremely busy, they're usually overwhelmed.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny introduces Shreyas's fourth big idea about a provocative tweet claiming that most execution problems are actually strategy or culture problems. Shreyas explains this insight he discovered later in his career - that in high-performing organizations where people have good intentions, what appears to be poor execution is usually a symptom of deeper issues with strategy clarity or organizational culture, not actual execution capabilities.
text_ko: 제가 모두 선한 의도를 가진 성과 높은 환경(high-performing environment)에서 접하는 실행 문제(execution problems)의 대부분은 사실 실행 자체의 문제라기보다 전략 문제(strategy problems)이거나 대인관계 문제(interpersonal problems), 혹은 문화적 문제(cultural problems)인 경우가 많아요. 예를 들어, 그런 환경에서는 빠르게 성장하는 스타트업(fast-growth startup)이든 빠르게 성장하는 더 큰 회사(fast-growth larger company)이든 많은 리더들이 정말 바쁘고, 보통은 감당하기 벅찰 정도로 과부하 상태예요.
text_zh: 在高绩效环境中，我遇到的大部分执行问题，其实大家的出发点都是好的，但真正的问题往往不是执行层面的，而是战略问题、人际关系问题，或者企业文化问题。举个例子来说明，很多领导者在这种环境下都特别忙，不管是快速增长的创业公司还是快速发展的大公司，他们都忙得不可开交，通常都是应接不暇的状态。
text_es: La mayoría de problemas de ejecución que me encuentro en entornos de alto rendimiento donde todos tienen buenas intenciones, en realidad no son problemas de ejecución - son problemas de estrategia, de relaciones interpersonales o de cultura organizacional. Para que se entienda mejor, déjame hacer esta observación: muchos líderes están súper ocupados en estos entornos, ya sea en una startup de crecimiento acelerado o en una empresa más grande que está creciendo rápido, están súper ocupados, normalmente están desbordados.
key_sentence: Execution problems often stem from strategy, interpersonal, or cultural issues, not right intentions.

text: When you are in a high leverage role, you should stop doing work that simply provides a positive return on investment, ROI. And you should start focusing on work that minimizes opportunity cost and what drives that is the observation that in a high leverage role, so product management is good example of a high leverage role, founders by definition are in a high leverage role, engineering leaders, design leaders, designers, these are all fairly high leverage roles.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny introduces the fifth big idea about prioritization - instead of focusing on highest ROI work, Shreyas argues you should think about minimizing opportunity cost. Shreyas explains this counterintuitive approach to prioritization that he learned by observing Patrick Collison at Stripe. The insight is that people in high-leverage roles like product management have hundreds of positive ROI options, but focusing on ROI can lead to choosing quick wins over truly impactful work.
text_ko: 높은 레버리지 역할(high leverage role)에 있을 때는 단지 투자수익률(ROI)이 플러스인 일만 하지 마세요. 기회비용(opportunity cost)을 최소화하는 일에 집중해야 해요. 그 이유는 높은 레버리지 역할의 특성 때문인데—예를 들어 제품 관리(product management)가 좋은 사례고, 창업자들은 본질적으로 그런 역할을 맡고 있으며 엔지니어링 리더, 디자인 리더, 디자이너들도 모두 비교적 높은 레버리지 역할이에요.
text_zh: 当你处在高杠杆岗位上的时候，就别再做那些只是有正向投资回报率(ROI)的工作了。你应该把重点放在能够最小化机会成本的工作上。之所以这样说，是因为在高杠杆岗位中——比如产品经理就是个很典型的高杠杆岗位，创始人天然就在高杠杆岗位上，还有工程技术负责人、设计负责人、设计师，这些都算是杠杆效应比较强的岗位。
text_es: Cuando estás en un puesto de alto impacto, tienes que dejar de hacer trabajos que simplemente te dan un ROI positivo. Y tienes que enfocarte en el trabajo que minimiza el costo de oportunidad (opportunity cost), y lo que impulsa esto es darse cuenta de que en un rol de alto impacto - por ejemplo, la gestión de producto es un buen ejemplo de un rol de alto impacto, los fundadores por definición están en roles de alto impacto, líderes de ingeniería, líderes de diseño, diseñadores - todos estos son roles de bastante alto impacto.
key_sentence: In a high leverage role, focus on minimizing opportunity cost, not just positive return on investment.

text: The main thing Google taught me was the power of thinking really big. And I know it sounds like a platitude, but really big. And I only actually realized that when I left Google and I started working with the other teams and these were all capable teams and I was struck by how many teams just limited the potential of what they could achieve. And I think Google helped people think big by default.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks Shreyas what key lesson he took away from each major tech company he worked at. Shreyas is explaining what he learned during his six years at Google. He emphasizes that while 'think big' sounds like a cliché, Google actually instilled this as a default mindset, which he only fully appreciated after leaving and seeing how other capable teams artificially constrained their ambitions.
text_ko: 구글이 제게 가장 크게 가르쳐준 건 정말 크게 생각하는 힘이에요. 상투적으로 들릴 수 있다는 건 알지만, 진짜로 ‘엄청나게’ 크게 생각하는 거예요. 그걸 진짜로 깨달은 건 구글을 떠나 다른 팀들과 일해보기 시작했을 때였어요. 그 팀들 모두 역량 있는 팀들이었는데도 스스로 성취 가능성을 제한하는 팀들이 의외로 많더라고요. 구글은 사람들로 하여금 기본적으로 크게 생각하게 만드는 환경이었다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 谷歌教给我最重要的一点就是要敢想敢做，格局要大。我知道这听起来像句空话，但真的要想得很大很大。我其实是离开谷歌之后才真正意识到这一点的，开始和其他团队合作时，这些团队都很有能力，但让我印象深刻的是，太多团队都在自我设限，把自己能达到的高度给框死了。我觉得谷歌的文化就是让大家习惯性地往大了想。
text_es: Lo principal que me enseñó Google fue el poder de pensar realmente en grande. Y sé que suena a lugar común, pero de verdad en grande. Y solo me di cuenta de esto cuando dejé Google y empecé a trabajar con otros equipos, y todos eran equipos capaces, pero me llamó la atención cómo tantos equipos simplemente se limitaban el potencial de lo que podían lograr. Y creo que Google ayudaba a la gente a pensar en grande por defecto.
key_sentence: Google taught me the power of thinking big, which many teams limit by default.
